commander.previous_service: Commander since March 1942, led division through Albanian/Yugoslav campaigns 1940-1941, reequipped in Italy summer 1941

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate - Division arriving with full equipment from Italy, supply lines via Tunis and Bizerte ports

weather_environment.environmental_challenges: Transitioning from Italian mountain warfare to North African terrain, learning desert tactics, Allied air superiority affecting movement

historical_notes.formation_history: Formed 1939 as one of Italy's original three armored divisions (131st Centauro, 132nd Ariete, 133rd Littorio). Named after the mythological Centaur.
historical_notes.deployment_context: Sent to North Africa November 1942 after Allied victories at El Alamein. Division arriving in stages - Semovente 75/18 assault guns among first reinforcements (Nov 12), artillery regiment arrived with full equipment by late November. Part of Axis effort to hold Tunisia bridgehead.
historical_notes.equipment_status: Well-equipped upon arrival with newer M14/41 tanks. 131st Tank Regiment (equipped with captured French R35 tanks) detached to Sicily, replaced by 31st Tank Regiment. Division at near-full strength during Q4 1942.
historical_notes.command_notes: General Calvi di Bergolo, King Victor Emmanuel III's son-in-law, experienced commander with Albanian/Yugoslav campaigns. Division learning North African desert warfare after mountain combat experience in Balkans.

discovered_units.justification: Historical records confirm Centauro's Semovente 75/18 assault guns were among first Axis reinforcements to Tunisia, arriving November 12, 1942
discovered_units.combat_evidence: Fought in Tunisia Campaign - Initial Deployment on November 12, 1942, providing self-propelled assault gun support for armored operations. Source: Comando Supremo - Axis Bridgehead in Tunisia November-December 1942

discovered_units.justification: During Battle of El Agheila (Dec 13, 1942), Centauro units coordinated with Tactical Group Ariete (remnants of destroyed 132nd Ariete Division)
discovered_units.combat_evidence: Fought at Battle of El Agheila on December 13, 1942, executing combined armored counterattack that forced British 7th Armoured Division to retreat. Source: Multiple historical accounts of El Agheila engagement

primary_sources: US Army G-2 Report: Order of Battle of the Italian Army (July 1943)
Comando Supremo: The Axis Bridgehead in Tunisia November-December 1942
validation.notes: Division arriving in stages during Q4 1942. Commander confirmed (Gen. Calvi di Bergolo). Tank counts estimated based on authorized strength and arrival reports. Some unit commanders unknown but positions confirmed from G-2 organizational charts. 131st Tank Regiment detached to Sicily confirmed.

gap_documentation.command.chief_of_staff.name: Not identified in available sources. Position existed per Italian armored division TO&E.
gap_documentation.subordinate_commanders: G-2 report provides unit designations and compositions but not individual commander names for Q4 1942 period. Ranks confirmed from Italian divisional structure.
gap_documentation.tank_operational_status: Estimated 92% operational (48/52) based on division arriving with new equipment from Italy. Actual maintenance records not available for Q4 1942 arrival period.
gap_documentation.detailed_casualties: Only aggregate division casualties available for Q4 1942. Unit-level breakdown not found in sources.
